awd_titl_txt: Human/AI Co-Orchestration of Dynamically-Differentiated Collaborative Classrooms
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will create and demonstrate new technology that supports dynamically-differentiated instruction for the classroom of the future. This new vision centers on carefully-designed partnerships between teachers, students, and artificial intelligence (AI). AI-powered learning software will support students during problem-solving practice, providing either individual guidance (using standard intelligent tutoring technology) or guidance so students can effectively collaborate and tutor each other. These learning activities are constantly adjusted to fit each student's needs, including switching between individual or collaborative learning. The teacher "orchestrates" (instigates, oversees, and regulates) this dynamic process. New tools will enhance the teacher's awareness of students' classroom progress. The goal is to have highly effective and efficient learning processes for all students, and effective "orchestration support" for teachers. We will implement and test this vision in the context of AI-enhanced mathematics learning in middle school. The proposed work will greatly enhance current understanding of how to design effective AI-based "co-orchestration" tools that draw on complementary strengths of teachers, students/peers, and AI agents to make the vision of the dynamically-differentiated classroom feasible. It will provide insight into the new classroom dynamics that arise. The work may ultimately contribute to more individualized K-12 education. The work will create a testbed that could be used to explore and rigorously test a wide range of interesting hypotheses regarding co-orchestration and dynamic differentiation of individual and collaborative learning. 

Effective orchestration of dynamically-differentiated instruction poses significant challenges in terms of design and technical implementation. Although existing AI-based learning technologies support forms of dynamic differentiation of instruction, they tend not to support dynamic combinations of individual and collaborative learning; in fact, most only support one of these two learning modes. In addition, existing teacher support tools tend to focus only on enhancing teacher awareness, not on supporting teachers' in-the-moment decision-making and action, and not on supporting dynamic interleaving of individual and collaborative learning. In the proposed work, we tackle this challenge by integrating and extending four strands of work: intelligent tutoring systems technology; a learning environment to support combinations of individual and collaborative learning; adaptive technology support for mutual peer tutoring; and a mixed reality tool ("smart glasses") to support teacher/AI co-orchestration. Building on this foundation, we create and demonstrate technology support for dynamically-differentiated instruction by three strands of work. First, we create AI-based tutoring software capable of supporting both individual learners and students doing mutual peer tutoring. Second, we develop a tool to support the intelligent, real-time co-orchestration, between students, teachers, and AI agents, of dynamically differentiated combinations of collaborative learning and individual learning. We do so through design-based research, prototyping, and classroom piloting. Third, we evaluate the newly-created technology for dynamically-differentiated collaborative classroom in schools, to gain an initial understanding of its benefits and challenges, and the changes in classroom practices and learning outcomes that it brings about.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Past research has found that mixing individual and collaborative learning activities can lead to better results for students than sticking to just one of these types of learning activities. In teaching, whether in K-12 or colleges, it's common for teachers or instructors to mix activities that students do on their own with those they do in groups, like "Think-Pair-Share" and "Jigsaw." Individual and collaborative learning might work well together and help students learn more effectively than either mode by itself. For example, learning in groups lets students share ideas and build knowledge together. Individual learning, in the other hand, might provide opportunities for skill development through repeated practice. 

Our project explored the value of allowing students to move between individual and collaborative activities on-the-fly, as needed, rather than (as is standard practice) following a set plan. This dynamic approach aims to let students learn at their own pace, which is expected to lead to better results. A key component of the project was creating and pilot-testing a novel socio-technical ecosystem - meaning that humans and smart technologies work together. The new system supports  dynamic combinations of activities in classrooms. Students are supported by AI-based tutoring software, specialized for individual learning or collaborative learning. A new “orchestration tool” makes it easier for teachers to manage the dynamic mix of activities in their classroom. 

We started with research involving teachers and students to explore how best to combine efforts between students, teachers, and AI. In the second year, we tried out, in a small number of classrooms, a rough prototype that embodied our initial ideas. The experience, though not yet very smooth, was quite well received by teachers and students.  We also surveyed 54 teachers to see how they felt about working with an AI-based orchestration tool and with students. We found that teachers liked the idea of sharing control with an AI to make managing the class easier. They wanted the AI to suggest which students should work together and point out any issues with these suggestions. However, teachers were cautious about letting AI make all the decisions, even when they were busy, and were at all keen on AI changing their (the teacher's) decisions.

We also analysed a past data set from classes using tutoring software to test ideas for how AI might decide how to team up students. We found that there is a balance to be struck between wanting students with different skill mastery levels to work together versus what is actually possible. This balance can change from class to class, showing the need for customizable grouping rules.

This research and development work led us to create a socio-technical ecosystem that supports smooth, dynamic changes between individual and collaborative learning. This system includes a new tool for teachers called Pair-Up. We also included two AI-based  learning programs for students, called APTA and Lynnette, respectively, for group learning and solo learning. We first tested this integrated system in a middle school to assess its feasbility. We found that such a flexible learning environment is possible and that the dynamic transitions are manageable for students and teachers. We looked at how this system changed classroom dynamics and how teachers and students felt about these changes. We found that teachers, to a large degree, were positive about the dynamic, personalized transitions between individual and collaborative learning, yet that there was some tension between how much control teachers and students want over learning processes. 

A second classroom study, conducted a year after the first, gave us new insights into how students learn when they can switch dynamically between solo and group learning, what value teachers and students see the value of this approach, and what we might improve in future tools. There was no difference in learning between dynamic versus pre-planned combinations of individual and collaborative learning, but teachers generally like the dynamic combinations better. These insights can help guide the creation of future systems that support learning, especially in advanced classrooms that offer more personalized and flexible learning opportunities.

Based on the project, we envision that future classrooms could use an ecosystem like the one we created, where AI-powered software helps students and teachers. Learning activities are constantly adjusted based on what each student needs, including deciding whether they should work alone or with others. Teachers manage this flexible process with the help of AI-based orchestration tool that makes suggestions but respects the teacher’s autonomy. We hope this vision, when it comes to fruition, will lead to better learning through greater personalization of the learning activities, with more and more targeted support from teachers, AI, and classmates. Teachers will have more chances to help students or groups who need it most.
